events.title: Miscellaneous Writing
events.description: By no means an exhaustive list of my writing -- but some of the Greatest Hits.

children.title: Why I'm leaving programming behind for a cheese blog
children.subtitle: Published in The Startup.
children.description: I guess programming is over now? And other thoughts on AI.

children.title: GitHub Copilot and major world religions
children.subtitle: Published in Geek Culture.
children.description: My little AI co-programmer is quickly becoming an indispensible tool. Let's talk about metaphysics-- wait what?

children.title: Shaping Young Minds with Agile Thinking
children.subtitle: Published in Geek Culture.
children.description: Why Agile methodology matters, and how I'm teaching it to CS masters students. If only someone had shown me these things when I was a whipper-snapper!

children.title: How many bugs should your product have?
children.subtitle: Published in CodeX.
children.description: It's a tough question, but it's one we should be asking ourselves: how many bugs should our product have before we show it to someone?

children.title: What you can't know about being a startup CTO
children.subtitle: Published in CodeX.
children.description: The term 'Startup CTO' can mean just about anything, depending on the startup-- but there is one thing they all have in common: wrestling with the unknown.

children.title: Embrace AI pair programming or perish
children.subtitle: Published in CodeX.
children.description: The future is here and the only choice we have is how to respond: do we reject it, or do we embrace it?

children.title: The Binary Search Methodology
children.subtitle: Published in CodeX.
children.description: A practical methodology for building software that I completely made up in a vacuum and is completely original.

children.title: Why Proof of Work is elegant and Proof of Stake is not
children.subtitle: Published in Coinmonks.
children.description: What can I say, I'm a sucker for elegant math. Proof of Stake is not the picture of elegance its older brother is.

children.title: Take the Time to Write Less Code
children.subtitle: Published in CodeX.
children.description: Something from Pascal the programmer: please take the time to write less code. Thank you.

children.title: Physics Engines Explained: Part II
children.subtitle: You thought the last article was deep.
children.description: Now the question: what makes physics engines break? In this article, I dive DEEP into linear algebra in complex space to find explicit conditions for failure. Believe me, it's cool!

children.title: Physics Engines Explained: Part I
children.subtitle: Get ready for some math.
children.description: An unusual departure for my writing: hard math. We dive into the theory of rigid body systems and begin an exploration into what makes physics engines tick.

children.title: Effectively Working in Teams: Baltic German Style
children.subtitle: Published in Geek Culture.
children.description: How can we understand each other? Thoughts from sociology, biocybernetics, and of course, mathematics.

children.title: NFT Collectors Are Geniuses
children.subtitle: Published in Coinmonks.
children.description: NFTs may be mathematically attractive but daggum if they aren't complicated. So complicated that most of them are horribly broken.

children.title: In which I probably invented a whole new branch of mathematics and computer science
children.subtitle: Published in Geek Culture.
children.description: My love for literature and math leads me down a strange path... Follow along in WONDER on a numerical exploration of classic authors.

children.title: Doug McIlroy vs Donald Knuth
children.subtitle: Published in CodeX.
children.description: Storytelling is a lost art in software engineering. What happens when you pit massive brains against one another?

children.title: Programming where Failure is Not an Option
children.subtitle: Published in CodeX.
children.description: Are we coding for space shuttles here? Why are we so afraid of failure?

children.title: Spherical Terrain Generation
children.description: Everyone has created flat procedural terrain-- but what methods can be used for generating spherical terrain? This two part post builds on geospheres and explores one method of geometry creation and one method for an accompanying Earthlike shader.

children.title: Porter Stemmer
children.description: An ancient and naive implementation of Porter's stemming algorithm. Essentially, it takes words and decomposes them down to their root.

children.title: Scorched3D
children.description: Now in 2D! An ancient, Scorched Earth style, software rendered, hot-seat multiplayer extravaganza.

children.title: Scorched Earth Style Terrain
children.description: For those of you wanting to generate interesting 2D terrains, similar to the Mother of All Games: Scorched Earth. These don't use silly fractals or perlin-- those are too boring!

children.title: Einstein
children.description: A relativity engine-- essentially any object in the scene can be the Observer, and every object has a clock. Both time and space are transformed by speed relative to the current Observer.

children.title: SOS
children.description: An XML log target for SOS Max that works across HaXe's AS3 and JS targets.

children.title: Jint-Unity
children.description: A Javascript interpreter for Unity.

children.title: Story
children.description: Story is a research project that leverages the Python NLT and machine learning techniques for gaming. It's a reverse text adventure. The goal is to use natural language input to describe an environment to a computer, which then makes choices about how to use the environment to accomplish the described goal.

children.title: Playing With Cinder
children.description: My first project using Cinder. It's very simple, linking luma from a video capture source to various properties of a bunch of circles (in the biz we call them particles).

children.title: Email Backup
children.description: A set of tools for backing up email. Yes, it sounds boring, but it was fun and I needed something simple.

children.title: Itsy
children.description: A cute name for an otherwise uncaring software-rendered particle system.

children.title: Dependency Injection in Unity3d
children.description: A couple classes for using Ninject as a dependency injection solution in Unity3d.

children.title: Kristmas Klein Bagel
children.description: A short exploration of generating a 3d immersion of a 4d Klein bottle.

children.title: Separating Axes Theorem
children.description: A very basic implementation of the separating axes theorem for collision detection. This was created for illustrative purposes, and has, let's say, a few bugs.

children.title: All Mine
children.description: A simple game built with Cocos2d that expands on Minesweeper. Energy, biodiesel, unit types and actions-- lots of fun stuff!

children.title: Telemetrino
children.description: Strapping an Arduino + accelerometer to an RC car.

children.title: Fabric Sim
children.description: A simple fabric simulation. Uses a spring system with point masses and Verlet integration. The original used my own graphics engine, but this uses ThreeJS.

children.title: boX
children.description: That's not an 'x' at all! It's a chi! A 2D WebGL graphics engine, twice as pretentious as LateX.

children.title: On Geosphere Construction
children.description: The geometrical construction of a sphere based on the subdivision of an icosahedron. This method creates a sphere where each triangle is the same size.

children.title: Realtime Clouds on the GPU
children.description: A two part study into noise functions and how they might be used to create purely GPU-based moving clouds.

children.title: Quicktype Maintainer
children.description: After major contributions to go, csharp, and prop-types generators, I was asked to be a maintainer.

children.title: UWP Support for Antlr
children.description: I used ANTLR to make a DSL for the Enkluplayer UI system. The only problem: it didn't run on HoloLens. This PR fixed the ANTLR project for UWP.

children.title: NaturalLogger
children.description: A Unity library for sending logs to Natural-Log.

children.title: Natural-Log
children.description: A socket server and slick client, wrapped in a cross platform binary using Electron.io.

children.title: Core-AVR
children.description: Libraries for working with 32-bit Atmel AVR microcontrollers. They are not good.

children.title: Stegasaurus
children.description: Hide data in pictures (steganography), which are then stored in plain sight: on Facebook. Stegasaurus encrypts data with a one time pad, which is then stored... in other pictures.

children.title: Ffabricator
children.description: A simple Akka + ASP.NET server that creates HLS streams from WebM or MP4 videos.

children.title: Nk-Js
children.subtitle: Web based SaaS Product
children.description: Nk-js is an end-to-end encrypted js library for use with nk-server: the no-knowledge store.

children.title: Nk-Server
children.subtitle: BaaS Product
children.description: No peeking. An end-to-end encrypted, no-knowledge key/value storage server.

children.title: Nano Watch
children.subtitle: Web-based SaaS Product
children.description: Nano watch is a simple web app that watches nanopool mining rigs and pushes browser notifications when the monitored rigs dip below a target hashrate.

children.title: Webtrono.me
children.subtitle: Web-based SaaS Product
children.description: Web-based metronomes are terrible, but not this one! A configurable, sample-accurate metronome in the browser. Create your routine and track your progress with your new practice buddy.

children.title: A Counterpoint to Account Abstraction
children.subtitle: In which I take on Web3's newest fad.
children.description: Account Abstraction, or Smart Wallets, are the newest fad. Everyone and their grandmother is making wallets. So why have we chosen to skip them for now?

children.description: Accepted into the Thirdweb Startup Program to bring our first game to market. This is a program for select startups to deep-dive their products built on top of Thirdweb's excellent products.

children.description: A typescript and react module for building games on Spyre.

children.title: Chain-chomp
children.subtitle: Custom cryto-protocol server.
children.description: Chain-chomp is an HTTP server for interacting with Spyre and USDC smart contracts, providing a gasless end-user experience.

children.title: Nakama-js
children.subtitle: A small but mighty OSS contribution.
children.description: An incredibly complicated fix deep inside of Nakama's JS library. Okay it was a one-liner but it was a hard to find one-liner.

children.title: A Complete-ish 3D Engine in 1200 Lines
children.subtitle: They said it coudn't be done.
children.description: Did I mention I teach in the CS Masters program at Saint Louis University? For my computer graphics course, we pair-programmed an entire 3D engine from scratch.

children.title: What is the point of higher education in computer science?

children.description: Now that I'm officially a highly professional academic, I realize I have no clue what I should be doing.

events.description: 'CTO' at Enklu meant 'guy that writes everything'-- and this was fun. After a stint doing 99% management, I dove into 99% coding again, writing the full stack for the HoloLens collaborative platform that outperforms Microsoft's own.

children.description: Enkluplayer is a collaborative, cross-platform multiplayer AR runtime that is unfortunately now closed-source. Live behavior and UI scripting across devices. Drag and drop asset import. Enkluplayer lets users collaboratively design and publish multiplayer-by-default AR experiences.

children.title: Enklu Cloud
children.subtitle: Web-based SaaS Product
children.description: Enklu Cloud is the leading platform for collaborative authoring and sharing of immersive multiplayer AR experiences.

children.title: HoloLens 2 Multiplayer

children.title: Conversational AI World Building
children.description: At another invite-only Microsoft hackathon, I created a prototype for a conversational world-building application using Azure's LUIS and Enklu. The computer asks what you see and builds the scene as you describe it.

children.title: Magic Mirror
children.subtitle: Location Based Entertainment Product
children.description: We were the first to adapt the Azure Kinect to live entertainment by adding Azure Kinect support to Enkluplayer. This ran as an interactive installation at Universal Studios in LA where lightning shot from your fingertips.

children.title: 100 HoloLens Multiplayer @ E3
children.description: We created the world's first 100 HoloLens multiplayer experience at E3. Over 7500 attendees were able to put on a HoloLens and explore magical powers in the Unreal Garden.

children.title: Kinect + Enklu + E3
children.description: At E3, we used our Kinect v2 integration to give wings to passers-by.
